message:
Guys if you manage a lot of servers and tired of keeping track of all their users ips and ports. check out https://github.com/GomaaK/sshez
It still needs some development work to include more advanced features but it is ok for normal usage. Your feedback/contributions are highly appreciated.
story: Khaled Gomaa shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: GomaaK/sshez
caption: github.com
description: sshez - If you have a lot of ips in mind. this is your keeper

data.message: what is the difference of using this command and adding your server ips in ~/.ssh/config ?
Nothing. Exactly like any generators you use, you can do it yourself but it is just much easier this way
but then what's the added value of using it?

I love having 1 liners that makes my life easier. I would never prefer editing maintaining a file by myself. I'm what you can call a lazy developer. I think this one is for lazy developers that want to automate everything they do.

Did someone say oneliners? :D
function sshez { u=$(echo $2|cut -f1 -d@);h=$(echo $2|cut -f2 -d@|cut -f1 -d:);p=$(echo $2|cut -f2 -d:); printf "
Host $1
	User $u
	HostName $h
	Port $p" >>~/.ssh/config;};
If you handled removing aliases and I will definitely use that. A gem is just an easy way to share and install that's why I did it that way.

function ssh-remove { sed -i'' -e "/^Host $1\$/,+3d" ~/.ssh/config ;};
note: you need GNU sed for this

And here the first one using sed too, less ugly than using cut:

function ssh-add { echo $2 | sed -e "s/\(.*\)@\(.*\):\(.*\)/%Host $1%^User \1%^HostName \2%^Port \3/" | tr % "\n" | tr ^ "\t" >>~/.ssh/config};
Cryptic bash one liners aside, I don't think that system tools written in ruby is a good idea..the version compatibility issues and conflicts are just too damn much...

it's worth mentioning that automating even the simplest and most trivial tasks is important... it just takes things out of the way and let's you focus on what you are doing, and makes you consistent and less likely to make mistakes...the tools used are basically a personal preference...

This is clearly a terminal utility, why is it in your README do you hint at the possibility that it could be used as a library by suggesting one can put it in a Gemfile? Does it expose any public interfaces and if so why aren't they documented?
